Everyone is mutually supportive and everyone tries to be democratic, but that's not the way the real world works. if you have an art show that has several excellent pieces of work in it and several bad things that the majority of people are going to look at and say, that's terrible. What's that doing in this show? People aren't going to take it very seriously because they're going to feel that But science fiction art is basically anything that's weird or grotesque and that there's no standards for quality in the field. There are some people attempting to form an academy of science fiction and fantasy art, and this may help a lot in establishing a basis for standards. Well, not standards. I'm not trying to get that across. A basis for quality. You know, for example, good rendering, you know, and basic things that make a piece of art good. There's not quite a place to come from it. Very little. I mean, what we have is, let's look at the Western artists. You know, the Western art has a heritage, a heritage going back to Remington and other artists from back then. it's got a standard of quality a benchmark with Remington and other artists for people to aspire to or to try to better even if their styles are more modern or whatever it does have that what does science fiction and fantasy art have well it's got the art of the pulps from the 30s and that's about it most of that art was real dreck let's face it when people look at it even among the general public it's considered pretty terrible art and a lot of it was some of it was excellent there was some excellent art from back then also but there was a lot of terrible work and there have even been books published of the art of the pulps and everything and this is what people see in the bookstores and they think science fiction art they think of the old you know the women in the brass brassiere fighting the tentacled monster you know in the cliche situations and with a bubble helmet and everything hopefully Star Wars and some of the new movies have been out in the last 10 years. We'll start to change that image and if people become more aware of the art on the books also, that'll change also. But we're still fighting to overcome the bad taste left over from the art of the 30s and 40s. The pull part. Have you had any inquiries into doing production design like Ralph McQuarrie? Yes. Yes, I've even got an agent now in Hollywood who's fielding those for me. I've had a few real weirdos come up to me with these great movie proposals, and I've wasted so much time dealing with these people that I've had to finally get an agent to handle some of those. I am working on a movie project now that may develop into a full-scale production. I don't know. We'll see. that I can't talk about, is what I'm getting into. I've signed a paper to the effect that I can't reveal any of the information about the movie until they choose to do so in a publicity release. What are you working on that you can't do? Cover. Oh, that I can talk about? I just finished the cover for Foundation's Edge for Isik Asimov. There's a new dragon book by Anne McCaffrey that I'll start reading soon. I've got another Year's Best Horror Stories cover to do next month, or this month actually. April anyway. What month are we in here? There are so many things going on. It's really hard for me to remember them all. There's the Final Fuzzy Manuscript by H.P. Lovecraft, I was going to say. H.P. and Piper. I am wrapping up a children's book, my first children's book. So that's a collaboration with another artist named David Wenzel, and it should be a real nice book. And let me think, we're doing... I'll tell you the truth. I've got a stack of manuscripts in my studio that's probably five feet high. And they come in, and I say, well, that looks like a fun one to do. And yeah, I can fit in my schedule, and then I put it in the pile and forget about it until I get done with the painting before that one is due and pick up the manuscript and say, oh yeah, this one. So I've forgotten what a lot of my projects are. I've not booked as much as a year in advance at any particular time and that certainly is the situation now. So I remember, there's some of them that I remember and those are the ongoing projects and the Dragon one because I've got a special interest in Emma Caffrey's work. but that's all I can think of off the top of my head. How many projects do you have going at one time, paintings with? Well, I usually like to keep it to just one. I hate to divide my interests between one painting and another project. I go to great lengths to maintain a mood throughout a painting. I did a painting that took place on a sandy planet, for example, it was all desert. and I recorded a six hour tape of all wind noises and like wind in a desert and I just played that while I was painting the painting because I wanted to keep in the mood and the feeling of that that book and that that painting so I hate I'd hate to be in the middle of that planet and that scene and trying to develop that this environment and then have to break it and do a painting of something horrible or whatever. But sometimes I'm forced to. And it's happened a couple times. But I'm usually good enough at juggling my schedule around so I don't have to. It is very beneficial sometimes to have a break after doing all the sketches. I've sent the sketches in to the publisher and they're looking those over for me to do another project because when the sketches come back to me, I see them with a fresh eye. And even though the publisher may have picked one particular one I may find a different one that I think it really is better for the book after all and I'll throw the other ones aside I'll talk it over to the publisher and we'll figure out a way to compromise on them or something or they'll let me go ahead and do the one I want to do but that is good to have a break between doing going through all the analyzing the collating and excuse me and doing the sketches and and before doing the final painting is could have a break in there but while I'm actually doing that the big painting the big rendering I hate hate to have to break that and do another one it's really that's one of the reasons why I have a strong dislike for advertising work advertising work always involves having to do extra work on a painting you know you do a piece it's the only time that ever happens to me never happens to me with paperback covers I get something sent back to me for changes but I'll do an advertising job and because well advertising jobs are almost always judged by committee you know men in the advertising company and someone always has to come up with an idea that makes it sound like he's worth being hired to work in this company so if a piece of artwork gets passed around for a particular client they'll look at it and say well I think this and everyone's got to have an idea you know and some of the ideas are the most stupid things I've ever heard in my life I'll tell you working for advertising companies are really something and And they'll think of anything to have some input in this particular committee meeting about my piece of work or any artist's piece of work. I don't know any artist that doesn't have things sent back from advertising agencies and stuff on a regular basis. And so I'll be working. I will finish the painting, send it into an ad company or whatever. And I'll be on the next one. And then this thing will come back to me because I want changes here or brighten up this or take this out or whatever. Then I'll have to stop and work on that other one. make the changes and send that back in and then I can go back to the painting I was working on and I hate that so much, that's why I avoid doing a lot of advertising jobs I mean I charge them for the extra work and all that and that type that kind of discourages them from sending it back to me but a lot of times it doesn't Let's get into Glass Onion Graphics a little bit why did you decide to open that up? it was a gradual process I'd always wanted to make prints of my work available most of my work sells for pretty high prices fans simply can't afford it when I go to a convention I like to have something they can afford to buy the way around that is by doing prints and posters of my work Glassning Graphics was created to fill that need Now, my wife has helped me out a lot by doing my bookkeeping, for example, and other things. She stopped doing what she was doing in order to help me out in my business to a certain extent. And Glass-Siner Graphics was kind of an extension of that. I said, if you want to go ahead and make a print of my work, I'd be really happy. You can take all the profit and everything. Just, you know, as long as we have print available for fans to buy or whatever. And she's turned it into a full-scale business. Now, she's still busy. She's on that phone. She's doing my bookkeeping and all this other stuff that we originally were going to – she was going to do. We've had to hire extra people. We have a secretary and whatever. But now it's going into a full-scale business.

segments.text: How was my trip out?
As usual, hectic and hastily planned, we always seem to, even though we have the best intentions
of getting everything together well in advance and very organized and business-like, we tend
not...
But if I ask a dumb question or something like that, just say, oh wait a minute, back
We chop all that stuff out.
Yeah, it's no problem.
Or if I make a dumb answer.
We chop that out too.
Okay.
Let's start off with the basic one.
When did you get interested or when did you're interested in art development?
I think it developed when I was born.
My father's always worked as a...
worked in the space industry or in the missiles and space industry,
So I had that input around me. He had always been reading science fiction since I was young, so I had the magazines around to look at.
And some of my earliest recollections are of looking at the covers of old amazing stories, magazines or paperback books.
And in fact, some of them influenced me to a great deal.
Before I could even read or write, I remember looking at some of those covers for hours and absorbing the visual feeling of the paintings.
There were a few that were especially captivating for me.
And I remember them to this day, exactly what the paintings looked like.
And I can describe to you the compositions and some of the colors of the paintings.
And it's a funny thing.
At the last World Science Fiction Convention, I was walking down by one of the dealer's tables in the dealer's room.
and I just started going through some of the paperback books
and I saw one of the covers that I remembered
from when I was three years old or whatever.
It was interesting to me because I hadn't been able,
in retrospect, to pinpoint the exact time
when I started really being fascinated by science fiction imagery.
And this book had been published in 1952 or 1953,
so being born in 1950 that pretty much establishes
the beginning of that at around three years old or so.
but the fact that it meant so much to me that I remembered that exact cover
until my present age says something about how I guess it was just a part of me
that that kind of imagery was important to me.
But later when I began to read, I became an avid reader of all types of literature,
but especially science fiction and fantasy.
And I had an interest in art, so the two combined,
and it seemed natural to me too.
to read and try to draw what I read.
And I would come home sometimes from science-fiction movies
or movies that I enjoyed and tried to illustrate scenes
that I'd seen in the movie from memory.
And that carried on pretty much right into my college years.
I can continue beyond that point.
Because in college, I had been laboring under the assumption
that I had to have a real type of profession.
This is largely due to input from my parents,
but I felt that I had to be something professional,
like a lawyer, something respectable,
which being an artist isn't.
So I was diverted during my college years
into wanting to become a doctor,
which is still a major interest of mine,
anatomy and physiology and the sciences in general
were always important to me.
But about three quarters of the way
through my college education, I decided to abandon my pre-med training and go full scale.
Well, actually, it wasn't until my last year of college that I decided a full tilt to go
into illustrating or painting, and I graduated with a degree in painting.
If I had taken one more course, I would have had a degree in biology with an emphasis on
anatomy and physiology, human anatomy and physiology.
To go up and attack on that, does that background, or how does that background help you when
you're painting?
It helps me a lot in several ways. First of all, in constructing alien forms by just extrapolating upon comparative biology.
I can develop a life form that's both interesting visually and somewhat convincingly suited for a particular environment on another planet.
There's that. And also, it helps me in constructing a human form because I did a lot of dissection.
and I know my human anatomy fairly well.
Whereas I know a lot of artists who don't,
they know surface anatomy
but they can't really construct a person
well out of their imagination
without at least the extensive use of photographs
and that's something I try to avoid.
I think it shows in an artist's painting
when one uses a photograph to develop the person
and then tries to create the rest of the painting
out of one's imagination,
you see a real dichotomy
between the way the person's painted
and the rest of the painting is painted.
If it all comes out of your mind, then it all looks like one product or whatever.
But one of the jobs I had when I was putting myself through college
was working in the anatomy and physiology labs at the university I went to
preparing the cadavers for the classes.
And during that time, I managed to get some work in doing medical illustrations.
All this combined to really give me a good fundamental education
in the way the body is made up.
You had some further training going in, are you?
Yes, after college I went to, I wasn't,
the teachers told me I was ready for a professional career,
but I didn't know what I wanted to do yet.
I mean, I still didn't, well, I knew what I wanted to do,
but I didn't have the confidence really to throw everything I had
into a career in illustration.
I didn't know really where to start.
So to get that kind of professional polish,
I enrolled in the Arts Center College of Design in L.A.
Now in Pasadena, they moved after I left.
But I only went there for nine months because I felt that they didn't have much to teach me after I was in there.
And a couple of my teachers advised me just to drop out and go ahead and start working.
So I sent some samples of my work to publishers in New York, and a couple of them bit.
So I threw everything I had into the back of my Volkswagen,
drove out from California to the East Coast to find my fortune.
Was one of those where Donald Wolheim?
Yes, Donald Wolheim of Daw Books was very interested in my work
and quite supportive, really, in my early years.
Just a bit of a story.
When you got your first cover job, how did that happen?
What happened there?
There was a couple of ways that it happened.
Excuse me.
And I had a portfolio of items.
You know, I came out to the East Coast and sat down and for two weeks, just painted straight through.
I came out with seven pieces in the end of that time.
Excuse me.
Hold that for me to cut out.
All my cough in the middle.
Anyway, I had a portfolio of pieces.
And I went around first to Marvel Comics.
You know, I'm starting low, at least in my opinion at this point.
I showed it to Roy Thomas, who was the editor-in-chief at that time, and he bought three pieces out of the portfolio.
So my first cover assignments weren't really commissioned from me.
They were bought from me because they were already done.
Now, it's true that after he bought those, he required extensive changes in the work, something that still bothers me to this day.
But anyway, that's how that happened.
Now, with Don Wolheim, he saw slides of my work, of course, in California.
And later I went in to see him when I came out to the East Coast,
and he gave me a manuscript for a book,
and I took it home, did some sketches for the manuscript
based upon ideas that I thought would make good cover ideas,
and he selected one and gave me the go-ahead,
and that became the painting.
That's pretty much how I work on every book cover.
Okay, Rob, I understand you're reading a manuscript now for something.
Several.
Several.
Yeah.
Why don't you go through how that process works for you.
What, actually?
Pick a specific.
Boy, that's hard.
Every book is so different.
How about that one?
Oh, The White Dragon, yeah.
That's going back a way.
That's back in 77 or 78 when I did that.
Let me think.
Well, I read the book one time, just read it as a reader, so to speak.
Then I go through it again the second time as an illustrator,
making notes in margins about details of the way people and objects and things look,
making sure that I try to catch all the details so I don't make someone who's blonde, black-haired, or whatever,
because I like to be really true to the story as much as possible,
especially if I'm taking a narrative approach to doing an illustration.
after going through it that second time i'll sit down and start to develop thumbnail sketches
which are just a small drawings um on scrap paper actually and try to formulate an idea of what i
i would like to illustrate from that book there's usually something in any book no matter how bad
or good that uh will make a good painting it's a matter of digging through it and finding
what interests you and what will motivate you to do a really good job.
So I go through it and try to collate all my different ideas
and put it together into a painting.
That is the mysterious part that I can't really describe to you,
how that happens.
I guess that's what makes me what I am,
is that process there of distilling what I've read
into something that's a visual image that captures what's in the book.
but that process takes a few days to do,
and sometimes I get an instant image.
The cover I just did for Robert A. Highline's book, Friday,
I had an instantaneous concept of what that cover was going to look like.
As soon as I finished reading the book the first time,
I had, I think, a perfectly clear idea of what Friday looked like,
and I knew that the cover to this book had to be a portrait of this character
because the character had such personality that really the book was written around her personality, I think.
And so that was my approach there.
With other books, like The White Dragon, it involved a much more laborious process
because there were so many good scenes to choose from.
It's hard to figure out which one would be the best one for the book and which one is my favorite.
So it takes a little bit more time.
Eventually, I come to somewhere between one and eight images that I think I like,
and if I'm terribly indecisive, I'll send it to the publisher or to the art editor or whatever
who makes that kind of decision in a particular company.
He or she will choose the one that they like the most and make the decision for me.
And then once I'm given the ball, I run with it and do the final painting, the major painting.
And that becomes a book cover.
do you need feedback from the authors
yes lots of times
in fact with Friday
I got a phone call from Robert A. Heinlein
about a
couple months after I turned in the painting
to Valentine Del Rey they sent him
a cover proof which is
a first run color tryout
of what the cover is going to look like
and he called me up to tell me it was
a little flattery I guess
he told me it was the best cover he ever had
on a book of his which is
is really quite a statement for someone who's been in the field as long as he has.
And to have an author tell me that I've captured a particular character or scene
exactly the way they had it in mind is probably, for me,
the highest praise that an illustrator can get.
And that really had me floating up by the ceiling for a couple weeks
to think that he would bother to call me to tell me that.
But sometimes before I do a painting, I'll correspond with an author
or talk to him or her on the phone to establish certain details.
With the white dragon, for example, I talked to Anne McCaffrey at length about the actual details of the dragons.
As she saw the dragons in her book, whether they had fork tails or tails that ended in a point or whatever,
or a barb or whatever, and what their skin was like and what the texture was,
so that I could try to capture her image of what they looked like.
It's kind of silly for someone who's an illustrator to try to make all that up
when you can contact the author and get the details,
if they're not in the book, straight from the person who thought them up.
When you did A Friday, weren't you working in a new medium airbrush?
Oh, no.
I've been using the airbrush since 1975.
The difference lately is that I'm using it a bit more than I was in the past.
Now, in Friday, there is no airbrush work in the foreground, in the figure.
that's all done with washes to create that smooth skin tone.
And I deliberately went about doing that painting with the idea of giving a real photographic quality to what you're seeing
so that you could reach out and touch her, so to speak.
Which is also a very important part of that character.
The background, though, is composed of a lot of airbrush work.
And I usually keep my airbrush work to the background because I don't want it to dominate a painting.
I hate to work an airbrush, frankly, because it's so tedious and I'm so clumsy that I often spill things on me while mixing up color into little bottles and all that.
So the only airbrush I have is the crudest model made by the Pache Airbrush Company, and that forces me to keep it to the background, pretty much.
I like to use it sometimes as a sketching tool.
an airbrush wall
develops soft masses
of color in certain areas that have no hard
edges so you can paint in and out of those
areas without creating distracting
I don't know what the word
would be, I call it background noise
but distracting
hard edges underneath what you're painting
on top
I think
it will be some time to come before I actually bring
my airbrush work right up to the foreground
and make a painting that's completely airbrush
My cover for Arthur C. Clark's book, 2010,
approaches that.
There is a lot of airbrush work
in the foreground there.
But that was such a simple composition
that it pretty much required that, I think.
What about using oils and acrylics?
I know you prefer acrylics.
Well, I prefer acrylics for illustration
because they dry so quickly.
That's the only reason, really.
Well, there's two reasons, actually, why I like to use acrylics.
They dry so quickly, and it's the main reason,
and that's the reason why I first started using them.
My training had all been in oils and watercolors,
and a lot of my early illustrations were in those two media,
but I found myself often working at 3 o'clock in the morning before the day,
or the morning of the day that I had to turn a painting in,
and I couldn't bring a painting in wet,
so I'd have to make so much drier in with the painting.
and there's a substance called cobalt dryer that if you put too much in the paint,
it seriously affects the longevity of the painting.
In fact, I have a painting I did in late 1974 that has now cracked up a lot in oil painting
because I had to rush it dry that way.
And so my feeling is if I can't paint an oil painting right so that it will last
and be a good investment to someone who may buy it, then I'd rather not use that medium at all
unless I have the time to be able to develop it in the correct process
so that it'll last for posterity.
So I use acrylics and it certainly is easier for me.
I can paint right up to two minutes before the messenger comes
to pick up my painting and take it to the publisher
and put in that last little highlight or whatever
and not have to worry about it being wet or being damaged on root.
Some people say acrylics don't have the depth that oils have,
but I had to notice the acrylic paints.
Oh, it depends on how you use them.
Yeah, I see a lot of flat acrylic paintings, frankly.
And that's just, I had to teach myself how to use them.
And I think my background in oils dictated
that I try to duplicate some of the feeling
that you get in oil paintings with acrylics.
And maybe because I approach it from that aspect,
I attempted to do that,
to get that feeling in depth with my acrylic set
and other people who have just had a training in acrylics only don't try to do that
because they feel limited by that.
The fast drying time is also a liability with acrylics.
It's very hard to blend large areas of color, and that's why I often resort to the airbrush.
I can do it with watches if I have to, but it takes a lot longer.
I did a painting for a book by Clifford Simmeck called City.
There's a big blue sky in the background,
and it took me 32 washes of color to get just the right gradations of blues in the background.
That took me about a day and a half or two days to do.
Now, with an airbrush, I probably could have gotten exactly the same effect in a half an hour.
So, you know, when you're working a 100-hour week or an 80-hour week like I do,
you know, a half an hour can make a big difference in a painting.
So I don't... I'm like... Wait a minute, let me say...
I don't work 80 or 100-hour weeks all the time,
but I often do. It seems like most of the last year I did.
That half an hour or two days worth of time
makes a big difference. I resort to the airbrush just because it is a good time-saving
tool, and I can duplicate the same effects.
I like oil paints a lot,
and I want to get back into using them just because
it has a whole historical, romantic
feeling to it.
It's really something that's hard to describe to someone who's
a non-artist, but the smell of
turpentine in a studio and everything
has a certain sense of nostalgia and romance
to it.
It is an entirely enjoyable experience to paint
in oils. It's a whole different
thing from working in acrylics.
I would like to go back into
painting with oils.
I just have to give myself the time to do so.
There is a problem I have with oils
which is the second reason why I use acrylics
and that's that I develop
skin problems when I get turpentine in contact with my skin, I seem to be allergic to it.
So I sometimes have to use gloves or whatever when I'm painting with oils, and that makes it
a less enjoyable experience. I like to have the feeling of actually holding the brush
without the barrier of this rubber in between my hand and the brush.
So that may be a reason why I haven't gotten back into painting oils.
I felt I felt really good about it but a little ambivalent I felt I felt like it
came a year too late because year before I done the White Dragon I had done the
entire John Carter of Mars series. I felt it was the pinnacle of my work at that time,
and that's when I felt I really deserved to get it. A year after that, I still hadn't felt that
I had bettered the work I'd done the year before, so I didn't feel, you know, this often happens
with Academy Awards, for example, that there'll be three excellent movies that deserve to get
best picture but the award can only go to one so they'll give it to one and uh they'll give an
award to the same director or something three years down the pike for a lesser effort but
it's partially in in acknowledgement of what the the person did before that they didn't get the
i've gotten what two or three more since then so um now it's uh you know it's easy for me to be
blase about it, and say, well, it's just an award, and it's great, but it doesn't pay the rent, and
it doesn't do a thing for my income, or whatever, but I'm not sure I would enjoy not getting one
either, so I'm not going to say. Other artists will ask me, well, how does it feel to win another
Hugo, or whatever, and I'll go, well, it's all right, or it's nice, but again, it's easy for me
to say that
because I'm winning them, if I didn't win it
it would probably really bug me
because I'm a competitive person
there are times when
I'm sitting down and I think
wow there's X number of thousand people
that voted for me as the best artist
that's really something that there's that many people
that enjoy my work that much
actually put my name down
as the best artist that they can think of
that's really something that really gives me
a boost sometimes
But you can imagine.
Here's a real art question.
And I'm sure you ran into this.
I have several friends.
Fantasy and space art.
And they went on to get formal training in the arts.
And they draw what was required in class.
But when they went through what they wanted to draw, the instructors got a little strange.
Did you run into that?
you run into it all the time it's getting worse if not better
I mean it's it's getting worse if it's not the same
there's only one school I'm an art school I can think of that
has opened up their attitudes towards that since
um you know since say 1972 now there could very well be others but
I know the Paris School of Art in in Connecticut has changed their
attitudes a little bit as a result of Don Mates who is one of their
major graduates and who is a Hugo nominee now
they have a little bit more of a tolerant attitude towards
science fiction or fantasy art. Unfortunately
you'll find a snobby attitude
towards fantasy and science fiction art among the public in general
it's just nearly impossible for anyone who does the type of work
I do to get into galleries to get
any kind of critical recognition at all.
And it's only in the last few years
that it's starting to show any hope.
Unfortunately, the art schools, as usual,
are years behind the real world.
And even if they started showing fantasy
and science fiction work in major museums
and galleries on a regular basis,
it's going to be a long time
until the art schools, I think,
catch up and start showing
a better attitude towards it.
But this is something I ran into.
that's one of the reasons why I dropped out
so quickly from ArtCenter
there's an instance where
that I can relate, there was a class
I had, a figure drawing class
and the teacher was late, hadn't come in yet
and the model was just standing there
and I had my drawing pad
in front of me and the model
was dressed up in an 1890s
type of get up and he had a bicycle pump
that was his prop
and he was just standing there
in this ridiculous pose that I had no interest in
I couldn't see any reason why I should have to draw that
I knew that I could draw it if I wanted to.
You know, I graduated already with a BA degree in painting at San Jose State University.
I'm capable.
I could draw that figure without having the figure in front of me.
It was no problem.
And so I just ignored him standing there and started drawing this picture of a giant,
well, he was a big, bald giant standing on a mountaintop,
a very heroic type of pose.
The teacher came in, looked over my shoulder and said,
What is that?
And then proceeded to scold me and give me all kinds of verbal abuse
about refusing to draw what was in front of me.
And I just packed up my things and said, that's it.
What am I here for?
This is ridiculous.
I'm not being taught anything.
By being forced to draw something that I have no interest in,
that I could learn nothing from.
So, you know, you find this in art schools all the time.
And there's also the situation where you have instructors who don't know how to teach how to draw realistic art.
One thing that I see all the time, I have art students corresponding with me.
Art students have come to conventions to see me and talk to me.
Where can I go to find out how to draw a person?
Where can I go to find out how to render something the way it looks in real life?
because all they're getting are classes in abstract painting,
how to express your feelings.
